thread.title: Mets-killer Chipper Jones: Rooting for New York in NLDS? (AUDIO)
thread.title_full: Mets-killer Chipper Jones: Rooting for New York in NLDS? (AUDIO)

author: Ryan Hatch | NJ Advance Media for NJ.com
title: Mets-killer Chipper Jones: Rooting for New York in NLDS? (AUDIO)
text:
Comments 
Former Atlanta Braves MVP and perennial All-Star Chipper Jones used to feast on Mets pitching throughout his 19-year career, particularly in New York. 
The former third baseman posted a ridiculous .309/.406/.543 slash line against the Mets and in 113 games at Shea Stadium (88 games) and Citi Field (25 games) from 1993 to 2012, socked 22 home runs, earning his place among notorious rivals in Queens. 
Fans often chanted "Larry!" when he came to bat. (Larry is Chipper's given name.) RELATED : Game 4, Mets vs. Los Angeles Dodgers: What's the weather forecast? 
But it seems Jones holds a special place in his heart for the Mets, which maybe isn't surprising, speaking out in support this week when their shortstop Ruben Tejada had his leg broken by Los Angeles Dodgers' infielder Chase Utley on a nasty slide into second base during Game 2 of the National League Division Series. 
Jones wrote on Twitter afterwards: That was not a slide and that is not how u 'go in hard'! â€” Chipper Jones (@RealCJ10) October 11, 2015 
Then on Tuesday, before Game 4 of the NLDS, Jones spoke to ESPN's Dan Le Batard on his radio show, offering his support of the Mets. 
"I hate to say this, but I actually find myself kind of rooting for them to be honest with you," Jones said. 
He went on to say it's partly because of Mets' righty Jacob deGrom . 
"He went to Stetson University where my godfather continues to be the head coach there," Jones said. "It's the same university my mother and father went to." 
You can listen to the full interview here:
